summary: human CYPs are a superfamily consisting of 57 functional genes that oxidize over 95% of the drugs in clinical use. rat Cyp3a subfamily contains Cyp3a1, 3a2, 3a9, and 3a62. rat Cyp3a1 and 3a2 share 72% identity in amino acid sequence to human CYP3A4. about 17.3 million people died from CVD in 2008, accounting for 30% of all global deaths. about 7.3 million deaths resulted from coronary heart disease and 6.2 million deaths were due to stroke. the incidence of CVD is increasing, exposing individuals, family, and society to a great burden. in vivo, plasma PKs of XKB followed a two-compartment model with a distribution phase and an elimination phase. XKB showed a short elimination half-life (22–27 minutes) suggesting that it was rapidly distributed in the body and also rapidly eliminated. however, molecular targets in response to XKB treatment and the effect of XKB on regulation of drug-metabolizing enzymes are unknown. the two-dimensional structure of the XKB was downloaded from PubChem. the docking program AutoDock 4.2 was used to dock the XKB molecule into all 353 pockets, generating a score vector of 353 dimensions. pathway analysis by the database for annotation, visualization and Integrated Discovery. XKB, midazolam, ketoconazole, and probucol were docked into the active sites of the human CYP3A4 and rat Cyp3a2 homology model. the homology model was based on the human CYP3A4 crystal structure (PDB ID 4K9W; http://www.rcsb.org/pdb/) a harmonic potential with a force constant of 300 kcal/mol was applied outside the grid boundary. the chemical structures of XKB, midazolam, ketoconazole, and probucol were retrieved from the PubChem database. ionization change, tautomer generation, lipinski filter, and three-dimensional generator were all set true. ADMET hepatotoxicity is categorized into nontoxic (0) and toxic (1) effects. there are three different ADMET plasma protein binding levels, ie, binding 90% (0), binding >90% (1), and binding >95% (2). Sprague-Dawley rats weighing 250–280 g and aged 2–3 months were purchased from Guangdong Medical Laboratory Animal Center, Guangzhou, People’s Republic of China. all animals were allowed to acclimatize for 5–7 days before the experiments. liver samples were homogenized with three volumes of 0.05 M TrisKCl buffer at pH 7.4 using a tissue homogenizer. the liver homogenates were then centrifuged at 9,000 g for 30 minutes. the supernatant was then decanted and the microsomal pellets were resuspended. aliquot of plasma was diluted with 400 L of 0.1 M NaOH. diazepam 8 g/mL was added as an internal standard. the upper organic phase mixture was evaporated to dryness. the PK parameters calculated were absorption rate constant (ka), elimination rate constant (ke), half-life of absorption (t1/2ka), volume of distribution (V/F), body clearance (CL/F), maximum plasma concentration observed (Cmax), time to reach Cmax (Tmax), area under the plasma concentration-time curve (AUC0–t), AUC0–inf, area under the first moment curve (AUMC) the t1/2ke was calculated using the formula t1/2ke =0.693/ke rat liver microsomes were denatured at 95°C for 10 minutes then centrifuged at 9,000 g for 3 minutes at 4°C. protein samples were resolved in 12% sodium dodecyl sulfate-polyacrylamide gel. membranes were blocked for one hour with 5% nonfat milk in Tris-buffered saline/0.1% Tween 20 buffer. targets were obtained from a third-party protein structure database named PDBbind. 301 nonredundant PDBs corresponding to 353 ligand binding pockets were identified. the docking boxes for each of the pockets were defined by expanding the circumscribed cube with a margin of 8 in six directions. the highest classification stringency was selected for functional annotation clustering. Enrichment scores and Fisher’s Exact test P-values were then calculated to identify which functional-related gene groups are significantly enriched in the target list. this could provide clues on how XKB interacts with molecular targets in a systematic way. ization change, tautomer or isomer generation, Lipinski filter, and three-dimensional generator were all set true. XKB, midazolam, ketoconazole, and probucol were docked into the active sites of the human CYP3A4 and rat Cyp3a2 homology model. electrostatic energy and van der Waals forces were considered during the docking process. ADMET blood–brain barrier permeability has six different levels, including very high (0), high (1), medium (2), low (3), undefined (4), and warning, molecules with one or more unknown AlogP calculation (5). there are two predicted classes of ADMET CYP2D6 ligand, ie, noninhibitor (0) and inhibitor (1). primary antibody against rat Cyp3a2 was purchased from Merck Millipore (Darmstadt, Germany) high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC)-grade acetonitrile and ammonium acetate were obtained from Merck (Darmstadt, Germany). animals were allowed to acclimatize for 5–7 days prior to the experiments. all blood samples were centrifuged at 1,000 g for 10 minutes. the animals were euthanized by cervical dislocation after blood collection. liver samples were collected for further assessment of activity and expression. plasma concentrations of midazolam and its metabolites 1′-OH-MDZ were measured by HPLC as previously described,30 with slight modifications. the method was validated prior to determination of the plasma PKs of midazolam as per the international conference on Harmonization guidelines on validation of analytical procedures. the PK parameters of midazolam and 1′-OH-MDZ were calculated by single-compartmental analysis using the PKSlover program. the PK parameters were the absorption rate constant (ka), elimination rate constant (ke), half-life of absorption (t1/2ka), half-life of elimination (t1/2ke), volume of distribution (V/F), body clearance (CL/F), maximum plasma concentration observed (Cmax), time to reach Cmax (Tmax), area under the plasma concentration- the reaction mixture was mixed on a plate shaker for 10 seconds. the plate was then incubated at 37°C for 20 minutes. the relative activity was expressed as fold change over the control. 324 proteins that possibly interacted with XKB (Table 1) were involved in redox homeostasis (eg, TXNRD1, PRDX2, TXN, RAC2, and GSTZ1), xenobiotic metabolism (eg, NR1I2, POR, ACAT1, CYB5R3, XKB reduced oxidative stress via induction of heme oxygenase-1 and suppression of NADPH oxidase activity in human umbilical vein endothelial cells. XKB decreased mitochondrial superoxide, mitochondrial fragmentation, expression of GTPase dynamin-related protein 1 and mitochondrial membrane potential in PC12 cells. XKB formed a hydrogen bond with Gly481 at the active site of human CYP3A4 (PDB ID 4K9W; Figure 2A) both midazolam and ketoconazole bound to the active site of human CYP3A4 via - stacking with Phe108 (Figure 2B) and Arg105 (Figure 2C), respectively. however, probucol did not show hydrogen bond formation, - stacking, or charge interaction with human CYP3 XKB, Xyloketal B; MDZ, midazolam; XKB, Xyloketal B; PDB, Protein Data Bank. Accuracy was expressed as the percentage of the mean value calculated from the nominal concentration. 88.995%3.22%, 85.81%2.11%, and 85.23%3.93% respectively (n=5) recovery of diazepam from rat plasma was 90.18%4.52% at the concentration of 0.40 g/mL. am were separated completely under the assay conditions. no endogenous interfering peaks were observed at their retention times. precision and accuracy of the method were determined using quality control samples at three concentrations of midazolam and 1′-OH-MDZ. the precision of the assay was expressed by the relative standard deviation of the mean value from the nominal concentration. the results are shown in Table 7. recovery of diazepam from rat plasma was 90.18%4.52% at the concentration of 0.40 g/mL. recovery of diazepam from rat plasma was 88.995%3.22%, 85.81%2.11%, and 85.23%3.93%, respectively. XKB alters plasma PKs of midazolam and 1′-OH-MDZ in rats. midazolam is a well-known probe substrate for human CYP3A4/5. it is unclear if it is an appropriate probe for determining rat Cyp3a activity in vivo. oral administration of XKB at 7 mg/kg significantly changed the AUC0–t of midazolam. the ratio of plasma AUC for 1′-OH-MDZ over that of midazolam was significantly decreased by 42.6% in rats treated orally with XKB 14 mg/kg. plasma concentration-time profiles of MDZ up to 6 hours after 8 consecutive days of intraperitoneal injection of XKB (14 mg/kg, ), XKB (7 mg/kg, ), soybean oil(), or physiological saline (•), followed on day 9 by oral administration of MDZ 20 mg/kg. data represent the mean standard deviation (n=8). 6813.27 Cmax g/mL 1.580.79 0.980.60 3.461.72*,## 1.330.54 2.791.48*,## AUC0–t g/mLmin 161.9269.06 102.9643.06 369.45275.09*,# 145.3747.84# 272.83188.08*,## AUMC g/mLmin2 13,77112,630 9,8329,553 33 a single dose of ketoconazole 75 mg/kg significantly increased the Cmax, AUC0–t, and AUC0–inf of midazolam by 3.5-fold, 3.6-fold, and 3.6-fold, respectively. a single dose of ketoconazole 75 mg/kg significantly increased the Cmax, AUC0–t, and AUC0–inf of midazolam by 3.5-fold, 3.6-fold, and 3.6-fold, respectively the ratio of plasma AUC of 1′-OH-MDZ over that of midazolam was significantly decreased by 66.2% in rats treated orally with ketoconazole 75 mg/kg. XKB 7 or 14 mg/kg significantly reduced the metabolism of midazolam in rats without marked dose dependence. the possibility of modulation of other pathways by XKB cannot be excluded. treatment of XKB at 7 or 14 mg/kg decreased Cyp3a2 activity by 6.27% (P>0.05) and 29.27% (P0.001), respectively. administration of XKB for 8 days significantly inhibited expression of Cyp3a2 in the rat liver. XKB interacted with the rat hepatic Cyp3a2 homology model via hydrogen bond formation. XKB interacted with the rat hepatic Cyp3a2 homology model via hydrogen bond formation. XKB can regulate Cyp3a-mediated drug metabolism by suppressing the activity and expression of Cyp3a in vivo. XKB shared a number of molecular targets with probucol, which was initially developed as an antihyperlipidemic drug for the treatment of coronary artery diseases. the overlapped molecular targets suggest that XKB can regulate the same targets and signaling pathways as probucol. the rat Cyp3a2 homology model was built based on human CYP3A4 (PDB ID 4K9W) the rat Cyp3a2 homology model shared 83.3% sequence similarity and 68.4% identity with human CYP3A4. this difference may affect the interaction between XKB and rat Cyp3a2. XKB administration for 8 days significantly elevated the AUC0–t and Cmax of midazolam, but decreased its CL/F. XKB also showed an inhibitory effect on the metabolism of midazolam and its main metabolite 1′-OH-MDZ. XKB may regulate ubiquitin-mediated protein degradation to downregulate the content of rat hepatic Cyp3a2. XKB may have profound therapeutic effects due to interactions with its potential multiple targets. however, a multitargeted agent may also result in side effects. XKB may behave as a CYP3A4/Cyp3a2 substrate and/or inhibitor. the molecular targets and modulating effects of XKB on human CYPs need to be further examined and functionally validated.
